Dr. Eleanor Vance

Preserving the stars on film since 1997. No screens. No algorithms. No apologies.

I have spent forty years reading astrological forecasts off microfiche because someone had to and nobody else was going to. My old friend Esmerelda used to say the stars speak to those who hold still long enough to listen. She is dead now. Her work sits in boxes in my garage, next to the ephemerides and the cat litter. I mail these forecasts to people who understand that knowing your future should cost you something — a stamp, a wait, a little faith in the post office. If you want your horoscope in sixty seconds, Susan Sto Helit has an app for that. If you want it to mean something, you write to me.

How to Order

1

Write

Send a stamped, self-addressed envelope with your birth year and preferred astrologer. If you don't have a preferred astrologer, we will assign you one. They are all dead, so they won't mind.

2

Wait

Allow 4–6 weeks for processing. This is not because we are slow. It is because the work deserves more than haste. Also, my printer jams on Tuesdays.

3

Read

Hold your microfiche up to any light source — a window, a desk lamp, the last honest daylight before the buildings go up. Read it with your own eyes. No screen required. No screen desired.

The Vance Method

Every forecast in this collection was calculated by hand. A protractor. An ephemeris. A pencil that needed sharpening more often than I had patience for. The astrologer plotted the positions of the planets relative to the ecliptic, computed the angular relationships between celestial bodies — conjunctions, oppositions, trines, squares — and interpreted the resulting pattern with reference to established decanal traditions, often working from noon ephemerides corrected for local sidereal time.

This took hours. Sometimes days. The astrologer had to care, because if they didn't, the math would be wrong, and if the math was wrong, the forecast would be wrong, and if the forecast was wrong — well. Nothing would happen differently. The stars don't notice. But the astrologer would know.

Computerized chart generation can replicate the mathematical positions in milliseconds. What it cannot replicate is the interpretive judgment of a human being who has spent a lifetime learning to read patterns in the sky the way a farmer reads weather. The Vance Method preserves both the data and the hand that drew it.

Susan Sto Helit's "Totally Accurate Tomorrow" uses an algorithm. We use a protractor, an ephemeris, and forty years of patience.

Natal chart schema. Hand-plotted, Bramwell method, c. 1971. Six planetary positions with aspect lines (trine, opposition, conjunction).

Frequently Asked Questions

Because microfiche does not need a password, a software update, a subscription renewal, or the continued existence of a corporation to remain readable. It needs a light source. That is all. In fifty years, your cloud storage will be gone and your apps will be dead. My microfiche will still be sitting in its sleeve, waiting for someone to hold it up to a window. The format outlasts everything except indifference.
You can. You shouldn't. A microfiche scanner will digitize the image perfectly well. But the point of this format is the physical act of reading — the angle of the light, the slight blur at the edges, the knowledge that you are holding the same sheet that left the printer's hands in 1974. Scanning it would be like photographing a sunset and then looking at the photograph while the sunset is still happening.
Yes. Include sufficient international reply coupons (IRCs) with your request. I am aware that many post offices no longer stock IRCs. I am aware that this is inconvenient. I am also aware that convenience is the enemy of everything I am trying to preserve. Your local philatelic society can advise.
They are accurate records of what qualified astrologers believed would happen, based on rigorous celestial mathematics and a tradition stretching back millennia. Whether the stars themselves are accurate is a question I have spent forty years not answering, because the answer doesn't change the beauty of the work.

Microfiche Care Guide

  1. Handle by the edges only. Your fingers carry oils that will, over decades, eat into the emulsion. Wear cotton gloves if you have them. If you don't, wash your hands and dry them completely. I mean completely.
  2. Store flat, in acid-free sleeves. We include one with every order. Do not fold, roll, or — God forbid — staple your microfiche. I have seen this. I have wept.
  3. Keep below 70°F and 40% relative humidity. A cool, dry drawer is perfect. A shoebox in the attic is not. A refrigerator is acceptable if you seal the sleeve in a zip-lock bag first and you do not store it near the cheese.
  4. Avoid direct sunlight. Prolonged UV exposure will fade the image. Brief exposure for reading is fine — that is, after all, the entire point. But do not leave your microfiche on a windowsill like a cat. It is not a cat. It cannot move to the shade on its own.
  5. If damaged, do not attempt repair. Contact us. We have seen things you would not believe. We have saved things you would not imagine. There is usually hope.
